Fig. 9 Insights into promotional effects for ethylbenzene dehydrogenation to styrene with steam over Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo mixed oxide catalysts Kaiwen Zha Methodology Investigation Writing – original draft Tieqiang Zeng Conceptualization Methodology Project administration Min Zhu Visualization Data curation Formal analysis Chunling Wei Methodology Data curation Lei Song Supervision Resources Project administration Changxi Miao Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Engineering and Industrial Catalysis, Sinopec Shanghai Research Institute of Petrochemical Technology, Shanghai 201208, People’s Republic of China State Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Engineering and Industrial Catalysis, Sinopec Shanghai Research Institute of Petrochemical Technology Shanghai 201208 People’s Republic of China State Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Engineering and Industrial Catalysis, Sinopec Shanghai Research Institute of Petrochemical Technology, Shanghai 201208, People’s Republic of China. ⁎ Corresponding author. In ethylbenzene dehydrogenation industrial applications, Fe-K based especially Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo based mixed oxides are the most widely used catalysts. But the corresponding reaction mechanism for promoters are still unclear. Herein, the model Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce, Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts were prepared by wet granulation method and the insights into promotional effects were clarified by using various characterizations and in situ DRIFTs studies. Our results suggest that Ce addition improved catalytic activity and Mo modification increased styrene selectivity. The Fe-K-Ce showed outstanding redox ability profited from abundant active oxygen species and reducible species. The Fe-K-Ce-Mo achieved optimal activity and selectivity because of the moderate redox behavior. The ethylbenzene adsorption at low temperature form coke deposits and enhanced oxidizing ability of modified catalysts facilitate CO2 producing thus improve catalyst coke resistance. Besides, the activation induction periods of modified catalysts were shortened based on accelerated formation of main active phase and redox equilibrium. Moreover, the steam significantly promoted styrene species generation and further shorten activation induction periods, which was involved in real reactions instead of just eliminating coke. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Ethylbenzene Dehydrogenation Styrene Mixed oxide catalysts In situ DRIFTs Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In practical applications, styrene molecules are the main components of various polymers such as polystyrene, styrene-butadiene rubber, styrene-acrylonitrile resin, styrene copolymers and so on [1–4]. Therefore, catalytic dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene to produce styrene is one of the most important reactions in petrochemical industry [5–8]. In general, styrene is produced by catalysis reactions of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation used with composite oxide catalysts in the presence of a large number of superheated steam at 600–700 ℃ [9–12]. Catalytic direct ethylbenzene dehydrogenation has always been the main technical route of styrene production, and its production capacity accounts for the vast majority of the total production capacity of styrene around the world [13–15]. The key point of catalytic ethylbenzene dehydrogenation technology is the high performance catalyst. The basic compositions of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation catalysts are principal active components, co-catalysts, pore-causing agents, enhancers and so on [16–18]. At present, Fe-K based mixed oxides with outstanding catalytic performance are the most widely used ethylbenzene dehydrogenation catalysts, which have attracted strong attention from researchers [19–21]. It is generally recognized that the Fe-K mixed oxides are restructuring at high temperature, as a result, two potassium ferrites of KFeO2 and K2Fe22O34 are formed [22,23]. The active state of the catalyst surface maintains a dynamic equilibrium between these two types of ferrites. Although potassium ferrite makes Fe oxide catalysts exhibit relatively higher catalytic performance, they are constantly deteriorated by harsh process conditions due to potassium loss and redistribution [24,25]. Kotarba et al. [26] revealed that K2Fe22O34 phase is the main cause of potassium loss and volatilization in catalysts by using species resolved thermal alkali desorption (SR-TAD) method. Meanwhile, KFeO2 phase is considered to be the main active component for ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reactions [27]. In addition, the causes of catalyst deactivation are also coke deposition, Fe3+ reduction, structure change and so on [28–30]. As for the reaction mechanism, Al-Khattaf et al. [31] estimated two Langmuir-Hinshelwood type kinetics models based on the experimental observations. The activation energies for the formation of the undesired products toluene (164 kJ/mol) and benzene (144 kJ/mol) were obviously higher than that of styrene (80 kJ/mol). And one type site Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism was properly consistent with the experimental data for ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reactions. Similarly, Fodor et al. [32] proposed several kinetic models based on a non-linear least squares optimization procedure. The Langmuir-Hinshelwood-Hougen-Watson (LHHW) kinetic model with surface reaction rate-determining step was found to appropriately describe the reaction mechanism of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation. The Fe-based oxide catalysts promoted by only K could not meet the needs stably of industrial application and commercial operation. Therefore, various other promotors are usually added to the Fe-K based catalysts in appropriate amounts to improve catalytic activity, styrene selectivity or maintain the catalyst stability [33,34]. Chromium (Cr) is historically used promoter which is widely considered to be a structure stabilizer known to have positive influence on catalytic activity and stability of Fe-K mixed oxide catalysts [25,32]. In fact, the Cr promotor has been proposed to maintain catalyst performance and hinder the loss of potassium during long-time extended operation. As for Cr-promoted Fe-K mixed oxide catalysts, the Cr species were found to interact with K species directly. In the real reaction atmosphere of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reactions, this interaction between Cr and K was mild enough to provide splendid balance environment relative to K availability to Fe oxides [25]. Kotarba et al. [23] prepared composite ferrite catalysts consisting of irregular KFeO2 and selectively doped (2 %Ce,2 %Cr)-K2Fe22O34. They found that the stabilizers of Cr and Ce played an important role in obtaining a stable composite Fe-K mixed oxide catalysts with high catalytic activity and selectivity. Actually, in terms of preventing potassium loss, the 2 %Ce-KFeO2 sample had a better performance than 2 %Cr-KFeO2 sample. In order to avoid the impact of Cr oxides on environmental pollution and biological toxicity, at the same time continue to improve the catalyst performance, more promotional additives are added to the industrial catalysts included Ce, Mo, Mn, Al and so on [31,34–37]. Li et al. [38] prepared a series of Fe2O3-K2O-CeO2 catalysts with various ratios of K2O/CeO2 by the wet-chemical method. The catalyst with optimal ratio of K2O/CeO2 showed best ethylbenzene conversion and styrene selectivity due to more active phase and stronger electron transfer ability. Moreover, higher CeO2 content could also increase the working life of catalysts. Abe et al. [39] investigated the effects of Mo addition in the low K composition range of Fe-K-Ce mixed oxide catalysts. In the ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reactions, Mo addition would attenuate catalytic reactivity of Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts but could prevent by-product formation thus improve the styrene selectivity. In fact, the Mo addition to Fe-K-Ce mixed oxide catalysts leaded to several types of molybdates formation on the catalyst surface, afterwards some active phase which attributed to by-product generation was covered. Up to now, the Fe-K based mixed oxides especially Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo based oxide catalysts have become mainstream catalysts in industrial applications [21,40]. However, the corresponding promotional effects and reaction mechanism for ethylbenzene dehydrogenation to styrene are still unclear and obscure. In this work, we fabricated Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce, Fe-K-Ce-Mo mixed oxide catalysts by wet granulation method commonly used in industrial applications. Various characterization tests were carried out including scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, H2-temperature programmed reduction, electron paramagnetic resonance, and especially in situ DRIFTs studies of reaction gas desorption and transient reactions. Furthermore, the insights into promotional effects for ethylbenzene dehydrogenation to styrene with steam over FeK, FeKCe and FeKCeMo mixed oxide catalysts are clarified. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The catalysts were prepared by wet granulation method (Fig. S1). Iron oxide (AR, ≥99.0 %, Sinopharm) and potassium carbonate (anhydrous, ≥99.0 %, Sinopharm) were weighed with the ratio of Fe:K= 4:1 (wt%), mixed well with an appropriate amount of deionized water. Subsequently, after kneading and extrusion process, the material was cut into cylindrical particles with a length of 5 mm and a diameter of 3 mm. The obtained samples were calcined at 800 °C in air. The prepared catalysts were denoted as Fe-K. As for Fe-K-Ce catalysts, the cerium oxalate (Aladdin) was introduced with the ratio of Fe:K:Ce = 72:16.5:11.5 (wt%). On this basis, for Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts, the ammonium molybdate (Aladdin) was added with the ratio of Fe:K:Ce:Mo= 70.8:16.5:11.5:1.2 (wt%). Similarly, the other steps of Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts were the same as the above preparation method of Fe-K catalysts. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) experiments were performed in a Bruker D8 Advances SS X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu-Kα radiation, λ = 0.154 nm) with a scanning speed of 8°/min in the 2θ range of 5–80°. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis and elemental mapping analysis were implemented on Zeiss Merlin Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) were implemented on a Tecnai 20 S-TWIN instrument. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis were performed on PHI 5000 C&PHI5300 spectrometer system of PHI corporation. The hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) were tested on an AutoChem II 2920 temperature-programmed chemisorption instrument from Micromeritics Instruments. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared transform spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTs) measurements were performed on a Nicolet IS50 FT-IR spectrometer from Thermo Fisher Scientific. All DRIFT spectra were gathered in the Kubelka-Munk format, accumulating 64 scans per minute at 4 cm−1 resolution. Prior to each test, each sample was pre-treated for 0.5 h and then regulated to the target temperature to obtain a background spectrum which would be deducted from the sample spectra. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements The catalytic performance of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation was evaluated by using 100 mL of catalysts in an isothermal stainless-steel reactor with an inner diameter of 2.5 cm. The following test conditions were used: reaction temperature was 620 °C, atmospheric pressure, liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) of ethylbenzene (GC, >99.5 %, Aladdin) was 1.0 h−1, and steam to ethylbenzene ratio by weight was 2:1 or 1.2:1. The reaction products were analyzed online by Agilent 5890 gas chromatography with an FID detector. The ethylbenzene conversion and styrene selectivity are calculated based on the equations as follows: (1) Ethylbenzene conversion % = ( 1 − C EB , out × F out C EB , in × F in ) × 100 % where the Fout and Fin correspond to the outlet and inlet flows rates in a steady-state, respectively. The CEB,out and CEB,in denote the concentrations of ethylbenzene outlet and inlet in a steady-state, respectively. (2) Styrene selectivity % = C SM , out C SM , out + C B , out + C T , out × 100 % where CSM,out, CB,out and CT,out are the concentrations of styrene, benzene and toluene, respectively. Additional experimental details can be found in the Supplementary Material. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and structure analysis Firstly, the morphologies of Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts were investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and the related results were shown in Fig. S2–S5. Without the introduction of Ce and Mo, the Fe-K catalysts were formed in irregular leaf-sheet like appearance. After Ce addition, there was no obvious change for the sheet-like feature of Fe-K-Ce catalysts except for CeO2 nanoparticles appeared (Fig. S2b and S4). These nanoparticles were barely presented in the hexagonal grains of potassium polyferrite, but were enriched on the surface of polyferrite crystals. Further addition of Mo, the Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts had similar morphology features with Fe-K-Ce catalysts (Fig. S2c and S5). The spatial distribution of different elements over the Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts was also investigated by energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping. As shown in Fig. S2d-i, O, Fe, K, Ce and Mo elements were dispersed uniformly in both dark and bright regions. As is well-known, the good dispersion of active components is important to the catalytic performance of catalysts [41,42]. The preparation method of catalysts could make the active components disperse well. XRD was performed to ascertain the crystal structures of Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts (Fig. S6). The Fe-K catalysts exhibited diffraction peaks at 2θ = 7.36°, 14.75°, 30.10°, 30.35°, 32.46°, 33.70°, 35.01°, 36.34°, 37.77°, 39.22°, 43.25°, 53.58°, 62.58°, corresponding to (003), (006), (110), (0110), (0111), (116), (021), (024), (119), (027), (0210), (030), (220) crystal planes of potassium ferrite K2Fe10O16 (JCPDS No. 40–0135). After addition of Ce, new diffraction peaks corresponding to CeO2 (JCPDS No. 34–0394) appeared over Fe-K-Ce catalysts. Further introduction of Mo didn’t change the diffraction angles of K2Fe10O16 and CeO2 over Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts, meanwhile the diffraction peaks of Mo species were not observed. This should be due to the good dispersion of relatively low content of Mo. 3.2 Catalytic performance The catalytic performance of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reactions over Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo mixed oxide catalysts were tested and the results were shown in Fig. 1. Under the test condition of steam to ethylbenzene ratio of 2.0 during 0–92 h, the Fe-K catalysts exhibited increasing ethylbenzene conversion until approaching a stable state at 88 h. The maximum ethylbenzene conversion of Fe-K catalysts reached 66.6 % at about 90 h. And it took about 25 h for the Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts to reach a steady state, whereas the activation periods were shortened by approximately 63 h. Besides, the highest ethylbenzene conversions of Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts could reach 78.2 % and 76.1 % respectively, indicating that their catalytic activities were significantly improved. Moreover, there were no great change for the styrene selectivity of Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts during evaluation time. The styrene selectivity of Fe-K-Ce catalysts was about 90 % under steam to ethylbenzene ratio of 2.0, and those of Fe-K and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts could reach around 94 %. The catalytic activity showed the following sequence: Fe-K-Ce > Fe-K-Ce-Mo > Fe-K, and the opposite trend was observed for the styrene selectivity. Combined with the TEM results shown in Fig. S3-S5, it was observed that the particle size of CeO2 nanoparticles in Fe-K-Ce catalysts was about 17 nm after counting. After Mo addition, the nanoparticle size increased to 25 nm in Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts. The relative less particle size also make the catalytic activity of Fe-K-Ce catalysts better. However, with a little lower ethylbenzene conversion, less by-products generated and higher styrene selectivity achieved for Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts. It could be concluded that the Ce addition could improve the catalytic activity for Fe-K catalysts, and the Mo modification made catalyst styrene selectivity increase. Gratifyingly, compared with the typical catalysts reported in the literature for ethylbenzene dehydrogenation, the Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts also exhibited outstanding catalytic performance (Table S1). Moreover, the coke resistance of Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce, Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts and the carbonaceous deposits formed over the catalysts after the catalytic test were characterized by Raman as shown in Fig. 2. Generally speaking, the band at 1300–1400 cm−1 is attributed to the disordered carbon species (denoted as D band) and the band at 1550–1650 cm−1 can be assigned to the graphitic carbon species (denoted as G band). It could be found that the disordered carbon species which were easily removed existed on the surfaces of Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts. After catalytic performance tests of 92 h, the distinct band around 1600 cm−1 attributed to the graphene-like carbon deposits appeared which were too stable to be removed readily. Excitingly, there were little signals of G bands arose for both Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts after ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reactions, implying that the Ce and Mo modification could inhibit the formation of graphitic carbon species thus improve the catalyst coke resistance. 3.3 XPS analysis The valence states of O and Fe elements on the different surfaces of Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts were investigated by XPS. Fig. 3a showed that the O 1 s bands were divided into two characteristic sub-peaks centred around 529.9–530.2 eV and 531.4–531.7 eV. It was generally acknowledged that the former ones were attributed to the lattice oxygen species denoted as Oβ such as O2− species, and the latter ones were ascribed to the surface adsorbed oxygen species denoted as Oα such as O− and O2 2− species [43,44]. It was widely believed that Oα species with strong migration ability and high reactivity were more active than Oβ species in the oxidation-reduction reactions, thus could enhance the catalytic activity of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation. The relative concentration ratios of Oα species of various catalysts were calculated and the results are also shown in Fig. 3a. Notably, the Oα species proportion of Fe-K-Ce catalysts (60.56 %) was remarkably higher than that of Fe-K catalysts (53.96 %) owed to more surface oxygen vacancies. This was also one of the most important reasons for the improvement of catalytic activity over Ce modified Fe-K catalysts. Furthermore, after Mo addition, the Oα species percentage of Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts slightly decreased to 58.57 %, accompanied by the mildly decrease in catalyst activity. It was worth noting that the Oα species ratio of Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts fell in between those of Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K catalysts, boosted to achieve the optimal state for catalytic activity and selectivity in the low steam to ethylbenzene ratio. In addition, the Fe 2p spectra of Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts were also measured to expressly reveal the surface state of Fe elements as shown in Fig. 3b. It was generally believed that the characteristic peaks of Fe 2p could be divided into two groups of sub-peaks, videlicet the Fe3+ species and Fe2+ species with relatively lower binding energy around 712.2 eV and higher binding energy around 710.1 eV, respectively [13,19,32]. Accordingly, after calculation, the Fe3+ ratios of Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts were determined to be 50.48 %, 56.21 % and 54.87 %, respectively. The modified catalysts exhibited relatively higher Fe3+ species percentages than that of Fe-K catalysts. There was a popular belief that the Fe3+ species had stronger redox ability in ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reactions. Most of Fe-K based catalysts were deactivated after a certain reaction time due to Fe3+ species reduction and Fe3O4 species increasing. Therefore, combined with the analysis results of O 1 s XPS, the Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts could show outstanding redox behavior compared with Fe-K catalysts thus make contributions to more remarkable catalytic performance. 3.4 H2-TPR and EPR analysis In fact, the redox ability of a catalyst plays a very important role in the whole catalytic cycle of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reactions. Therefore, the reduction process of the Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts were investigated by H2-TPR ( Fig. 4a). The TPR profiles showed that the initial reduction temperatures for all catalysts were around 320 ℃ and broad peaks with several overlapping peaks in the range of 400–650 ℃. Based on the limiting of reduction temperature and thermodynamic feasibility, the H2 consumption and reduction peak appearing mainly originated from Fe oxides and Ce oxides [40]. As is well-known, the reduction of Fe3+ species went through following process: Fe3+ → Fe2+ (low temperature peak) and Fe2+ → Fe (high temperature peak) [11,19,31]. As for Fe-K catalysts, there were two reduction peaks around 573 ℃ and 624 ℃ which could be resulted from the reduction of K2Fe10O16 → FeO and FeO → Fe, respectively. After Ce oxides introduction, the corresponding two reduction peaks of Fe-K-Ce catalysts shifted to 536 ℃ and 575 ℃. Meanwhile, there was a shoulder peak around 422 ℃ appeared in the low temperature range. In fact, reduction of pure CeO2 has been extensively reported which could be attributed to two stages of reduction of the surface shell at lower temperatures and bulk CeO2 at higher temperatures. Due to the similar crystal structures of CeO2 and Ce2O3, the Ce4+ and Ce3+ could easily coexist. In the reduction processes of Fe oxides, the surface Ce4+ species were also reduced in the temperature range of 400–650 ℃. Therefore, reduction of the Ce4+ species themselves and boosted Fe oxides reducing made the reduction temperatures move to lower temperature range, indicating that the Fe-K-Ce catalysts had stronger redox ability and better catalytic activity. Furthermore, similar to those of Fe-K catalysts, there were two reduction peaks around 551 ℃ and 616 ℃ emerged for Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts. Although the reduction peak temperatures of Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts were higher than those of Fe-K-Ce catalysts, they were still lower compared with Fe-K catalysts. The variation tendency was well consistent with the above results of catalytic performance and XPS analysis. Furthermore, it is well known that EPR is an effective means to investigate the surface oxygen vacancies. As shown in Fig. 4b, obvious signals at g = 2.003 were observed, which were thought to be the response of electrons trapped by oxygen vacancies [8,45]. After Ce introduction, the signal of Fe-K-Ce catalysts was much stronger than that of Fe-K catalysts, indicating that the Fe-K-Ce catalysts had more oxygen vacancies. However, the Mo addition decreased the content of oxygen vacancies slightly over Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts. In addition, the O2-TPD characterization was performed to estimate the O2 desorption behavior and the amounts of oxygen species for different catalysts (Fig. S8). The main desorption peaks of all catalysts were almost around 641–645 ℃ matched with the actual catalytic reaction temperatures. It was obvious that the peak areas of Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts were greater than that of Fe-K catalysts. Specifically, the desorption amounts of oxygen species for Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts were 3.24, 4.21 and 3.81 mmol/g, respectively. It was inspiring that the O2-TPD results were in well agreement with the above discussions of XPS and EPR. 3.5 In situ DRIFTs studies of adsorption and desorption In order to get deeper investigation into the ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reactions, the in situ diffuse reflectance infrared flourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTs) was implemented. Besides, the commercial catalysts (CAT) were added in the comparison to make the promotional effects clearer. The in situ DRIFTs of Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce, Fe-K-Ce-Mo and CAT catalysts with temperature rising after adsorption of ethylbenzene for 1 h at 30 ℃ were measured and the results are shown in Fig. 5. By contrast, the various band locations by ethylbenzene adsorption on the surfaces of the four catalysts were roughly similar, indicating that the species formed were basically the same. Concretely, the bands around 3400 cm−1, 2326–2363 cm−1, 1497–1509 and 1066–1089 cm−1, 1376–1463 cm−1 were attributed to vibrations of hydroxyl group species, carbon dioxide molecules, C-C bonds of ethylbenzene molecules, C-H bonds of ethylbenzene molecules, respectively [1,3,9,30,46]. It was speculated that the chemical adsorption of ethylbenzene on the catalyst surface at low temperature would form a small amount of coke deposits, which could react with the active oxygen species on the catalyst surface to form carbon dioxide. Compared with the in situ DRIFTs spectra of Fe-K catalysts, the addition of Ce could enhance the band intensity of Fe-K-Ce catalysts in the wavenumber range of 2349–2360 cm−1, indicating that the oxidizing ability of catalysts was improved and thus the carbon dioxide species were enhanced. Sequentially, when Mo element was introduced, the band signal of carbon dioxide species was weakened and that of ethylbenzene molecules was enhanced, manifesting that the Mo addition could enhance the adsorption of ethylbenzene and reduce the oxidation ability of Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts to some extent (Fig. S9). These results were well tally with the above Raman data and discussion. As for CAT catalysts, not only the ethylbenzene adsorption was stronger, but also the band intensity of carbon dioxide species was enhanced, indicating that the CAT catalysts exhibited the suitable state in terms of oxidizing ability and reactant adsorption. Furthermore, with the increase of temperature, the band vibration intensities of the surface species gradually decreased. Meanwhile the infrared band signal of carbon dioxide species continually appeared until complete desorption under high temperature (Fig. S10). This implied that the catalytic activity of various catalysts including reactivity of surface active oxygen species increased gradually as the temperature rising. 3.6 In situ DRIFTs studies of transient reactions In order to investigate the change of catalyst surface species and explore the reaction mechanism of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reactions, the in situ DRIFTs studies of transient reactions of ethylbenzene and ethylbenzene + steam were studied. Herein, the test temperature was chosen to 620 ℃, which was the same as that of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation in practice. Under this temperature, all the catalysts could exhibit sufficient catalytic performance, so that obvious differences in real reactions could be observed. The in situ DRIFTs studies of transient reactions of ethylbenzene reaction gas at 620 °C over Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce, Fe-K-Ce-Mo and CAT catalysts as a function of time were shown in Fig. 6. When ethylbenzene reaction gas was introduced at 620 ℃, the band wavenumber locations of species signals on the four catalyst surfaces were roughly the same. Specifically speaking, the characteristic bands around 1138–1218 cm−1 could be attributed to the vibration of styrene molecules, the bands around 1389–1419 cm−1 were ascribed to C-H bond vibration of methyl groups in ethylbenzene molecules [9,46]. This showed that the four catalysts could catalyze the dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene to styrene by simply adding ethylbenzene reaction gas, and the adsorption of ethylbenzene species could also be observed on the surface. As shown in Fig. 6, within the 60 min of test time, the band intensities of styrene species over Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce, Fe-K-Ce-Mo and CAT catalysts reached 0.50, 0.59, 0.63 and 0.98, respectively. It could be known that the modification of Ce and Ce-Mo oxides could improve the catalytic performance compared with Fe-K catalysts. Even in the absence of steam, the band intensity of styrene species over CAT catalysts after 60 min’ reaction time was close to twice that of Fe-K catalysts, implying that the addition of other modification additives would significantly improve the catalytic performance. Combined with the increasing trend of Kubelka-Munk intensities of the bands belonged to styrene species over time ( Fig. 7), it could be seen that the band intensity of styrene species over Fe-K catalysts increased rapidly from 47 min and became stable at around 53 min. This phenomenon indicated that there was an induction period in the ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reactions for Fe-K catalysts. Nevertheless, the band intensities of styrene species over Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts were continuously enhanced during 60 min. As for CAT catalysts, the band intensities of styrene species were basically consistent with those of Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts during the first 16 min’ test, significantly increased from 0.29 to 0.82 in the time range of 16–35 min, then increased relatively slowly after 35 min. Based on the above results, it could be concluded that the catalytic performance of the modified catalysts would be improved obviously even in the reaction conditions of pure ethylbenzene existed, furthermore the induction periods were shorten to make the catalysts reach the high-reactivity state faster. Combined with above results and analysis, it should because the promoters accelerated the main active phase formation of potassium polyferrite and boosted reaching equilibrium of oxidation-reduction cycles. To further investigate the roles of steam in ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reactions and simulate the real reaction environment, the in situ DRIFTs studies of transient reactions of ethylbenzene + steam at 620 °C over Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce, Fe-K-Ce-Mo and CAT catalysts as a function of time were performed and the results were shown in Fig. 8. Similarly, the ethylbenzene + steam reaction gas was introduced at 620 °C, the bands in the range of 1130–1218 cm−1 over the four catalysts were attributed to the vibration of styrene molecules. However, there were no conspicuous characteristic bands of C-H bond vibration belonged to methyl groups in ethylbenzene molecules in the wavenumber range of 1396–1421 cm−1. This was supposed to because conversion rate of ethylbenzene species was higher than that of surface adsorption and accumulation, so the infrared signal of ethylbenzene species on the catalyst surface could not be observed distinctly. This also indirectly indicated that the introduction of steam might change the original reaction path of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation, thus had noteworthy influence on the catalytic performance of the four catalysts. As shown in Fig. 8, within the 60 min of test time, the band intensities of styrene species over Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce, Fe-K-Ce-Mo and CAT catalysts reached 0.81, 0.99, 1.20 and 1.65, respectively. Compared with the above in situ DRIFTs results of single ethylbenzene reactions, it could be inferred that the introduction of steam could significantly promote the forward movement of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reaction, thus accelerate the generation of styrene species and enhance the catalytic activity of the four catalysts. This phenomenon could prove that the steam played an important role in the ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reactions. Moreover, combined with the changes of Kubelka-Munk intensities of the bands assigned to styrene species along with time ( Fig. 9), it could be observed that the band intensities of styrene species over Fe-K catalysts increased rapidly from 23 min, and the signal accumulation rate slowed down from 37 min. The styrene signal intensities of Fe-K-Ce catalysts increased sharply in the time range of 7–11 min and reached the maximum intensity of 0.99 at 11 min, then decreased slightly to level off at 23 min. As for Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts, the change trend of the styrene band intensities was similar to that of Fe-K-Ce catalysts which increased rapidly from 6 min and approached the maximum value at 16 min, then decreased slowly and gradually stabilized at 37 min. For CAT catalysts, the increase rate of the styrene signal intensities in the first 18 min was approximately close to that of Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts, but it still maintained a very obvious accumulation after 18 min, and finally reached a stable state around 43 min. According to the in situ DRIFTs results of transient reactions of ethylbenzene and ethylbenzene + steam over four catalysts, it could be clearly seen that the induction periods of the all catalysts were greatly shortened by the addition of steam, thus the catalytic performance of the catalysts would reach the optimal state in a shorter time. More importantly, the steam did more than just eliminate coke deposits, which was involved in real ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reactions [31]. 4 Conclusion In summary, the Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce, Fe-K-Ce-Mo mixed oxide catalysts were prepared and the corresponding promotional effects and reaction mechanism for ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reactions with steam were clarified. Under conventional steam to ethylbenzene ratio, the catalytic activity showed the following sequence: Fe-K-Ce > Fe-K-Ce-Mo > Fe-K, and the opposite trend was observed for the styrene selectivity. It could be known that the Ce addition could improve the catalytic activity and Mo modification could increase the styrene selectivity. The Ce and Mo modification could inhibit the formation of graphitic carbon and improve the catalyst coke resistance. The Fe-K catalysts were formed in crystal structure of potassium ferrite K2Fe10O16 and Ce addition could make CeO2 nanoparticles appear. Further introduction of Mo didn’t change the morphology and crystal forms of Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts. Combined with the results of XPS, H2-TPR, EPR and O2-TPD, the Fe-K-Ce catalysts showed much better redox behavior than Fe-K catalysts profited from more active oxygen species and reducible species. Besides, the redox ability of Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts fell in between those of Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K catalysts, boosted to achieve the optimal state for catalytic activity and selectivity. Based on in situ DRIFTs studies, the chemical adsorption of ethylbenzene on the catalyst surface at low temperature would form a small amount of coke deposits and the oxidizing ability of Fe-K-Ce catalysts was improved at higher temperature thus the CO2 species enhanced. And the Mo addition could enhance the adsorption of ethylbenzene and reduce the oxidation ability of Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts. In addition, the activation induction periods of Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts were shortened compared with Fe-K catalysts. It should because the promoters accelerated the main active phase formation of potassium polyferrite and boosted reaching equilibrium of oxidation-reduction cycles. Furthermore, the steam could significantly promote the forward movement of ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reaction, thus accelerate the generation of styrene species. The induction periods of the all catalysts were greatly shortened by the addition of steam which was involved in real ethylbenzene dehydrogenation reactions. Therefore, the investigations in this work may contribute great efforts to promising catalysts with excellent catalytic performance for ethylbenzene dehydrogenation to styrene with steam. coredata.dc:description: In ethylbenzene dehydrogenation industrial applications, Fe-K based especially Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo based mixed oxides are the most widely used catalysts. But the corresponding reaction mechanism for promoters are still unclear. Herein, the model Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce, Fe-K-Ce-Mo catalysts were prepared by wet granulation method and the insights into promotional effects were clarified by using various characterizations and in situ DRIFTs studies. Our results suggest that Ce addition improved catalytic activity and Mo modification increased styrene selectivity. The Fe-K-Ce showed outstanding redox ability profited from abundant active oxygen species and reducible species. The Fe-K-Ce-Mo achieved optimal activity and selectivity because of the moderate redox behavior. The ethylbenzene adsorption at low temperature form coke deposits and enhanced oxidizing ability of modified catalysts facilitate CO2 producing thus improve catalyst coke resistance. Besides, the activation induction periods of modified catalysts were shortened based on accelerated formation of main active phase and redox equilibrium. Moreover, the steam significantly promoted styrene species generation and further shorten activation induction periods, which was involved in real reactions instead of just eliminating coke.
coredata.dc:title: Insights into promotional effects for ethylbenzene dehydrogenation to styrene with steam over Fe-K, Fe-K-Ce and Fe-K-Ce-Mo mixed oxide catalysts
